div.l: And sawe a litle shymering of light
For at an hole þe mone shone in ful briȝt
And bi the light she saw hem both two
But sicurli she nyst nat who was who
But as she saw a white þing in hir iye
And whan she gan̄ this white þing aspye
She wend the clerc had worn̄ a volupere
And with the staffe she drue ay nere ⁊and ner͗e
And wend haue hitte this aleyn̄ atte fulle
And smote the mylner on̄ the pilled sculle
That doun̄ he goth and cried harow I dye
These clerkis bette him wel and lete him lye
And greythen̄ hem and took þeir͗e hors anon̄
And eke their mele and on þeir͗e wey þei gon̄
And at mylne yit thei took their cake
Of half a busshel flour right wel y bake
¶Thus is the proude mylner wel y bete
And hath y lost the grinding of the whete
And y paied for the souper eueridele
Of aleyne and of Iohn that bette him wele
His wif is swyued and his doughtir alsoeoe
Lo such it is a mylner͗e forto be fals
And therto this ꝓprouerbe is seid ful soth
Him thar not wene wel that ill dothe
A gilour shal him seluen̄ begiled be
And god that sittith in his maiestee
Save all this cumpany gret ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quitte the mylners tale
The prolog of the lawyer̉e
O hatefull harm condicioıı̄un̄ of poủert
With thirst wᵗith cold wᵗith hung̉er so cōnfoundid
To ax helpe thee shameþ in þine hert
Yf thou none axe so sore artow y woundid
That veray nede vnwrappith al þi woundꝭes hid
Maugre thyne hede þou must for indigence
Eythir stele or begge or borow thi dispence
